review_title: Great people, great work, leads the industry
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great people, great work, leads the industry
cons: I must enter at least 5 words

pros: Can use PTO in 15 minute increments
cons: Sick and PTO arent separated. Micromanagement. Lack of community feel and connection. BOS are underpaid, underappreciated and neglected

pros:
I've been with BDT through many stages of its growth and in several positions, and I believe that the organization is truly unlike any other. I am leaving to go to grad school in about two months and I do fear that I will never find an environment or opportunity that compares to my time here. 

Many companies and employers advertise that their work is "game-changing" and "innovative", but in my time here, I've actually seen the work that we do influence and inform social policy and industry practice. Colleagues at every level engage each other not only to better themselves, but to actually further the work they are doing - a rare combination. If you want to help lead work that is redefining how we take care of our neighbors and how government serves its citizens, there is a place for you here - analyst, programmer, policy wonk, communications pro, business major, social worker.

‘Working at BDT has helped me grow more than any previous experience I've had. My
mentors and peers here have encouraged me to not only find my voice, but to strengthen it - all in the name of serving others. My time here has strengthened my vision for what I want out of life and helped me develop invaluable decision-making, operational, and interpersonal skills. I really feel like I am my best self at BDT; I will miss it like nothing else.
cons: I've encountered no "con" here that hasn't been addressed quickly and effectively, from "questionable" break room coffee to communication issues.

review_title: Hard Work, Great People, Average Pay, Nice Benefits
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Training is very extensive to ensure information is understood before being 'thrown to the wolves'
cons: Pay is average, and sometimes the days can be mentally and emotionally taxing, but you are encouraged to take time for yourself as you need

pros: The people who work here are nice.
cons: The job can be repetitive.

job_title: Admin- Director Level in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Culture, people, mission, the work, work/life balance, the org cares about and appreciates its staff, diversity, everyone is SO smart
cons: Amount of work, communication, so many meetings, everyone is SO smart

pros: Positive workplace, compassionate staff, great opportunities for professional development and advancement, good benefits
cons: Salary is average but not exceptional

review_title: Great employees but poor management, poor pay and lack of career growth
pros: Great passionate and talented employees. The office and work environment is nice and the mission and culture is good. Office Politics and chaos have turned a great environment sour.
cons:
Management is really misguided. Positions are posted only to be removed later. The turnover rate is extremely high. We have lost a handful of very talented employees in engineering,  data science, UX, programs and IT in the past year.  Loss of some key employees has made some daily operations come to a grind because current staff have no idea how to operate these tools.
Decisions are made in secret without letting the team know until they have been made. Employees are brought externally because they are friends or know directors or C suite level employees.
There is no clear career trajectory. Most companies have a career growth plan for employees but not at this company. Pay is also way below market level wage. Their excuse is that we are a non profit while directors and the c suite are paid way above average while support staff are drastically underpaid. 
The organization has also become very top heavy with no clear direction from management.
Work suffers because lack of focus and clear idea of what the product should be. Products are patched together and released before fully ready.

pros: BDT hires empathetic and compassionate people to be BOS, so the coworkers and team leaders tend to be nice. The office is right I  center city, so that's convenient.
cons:
When BOS start, they're told stories of how other employees were quickly hired out of the contact center and into better positions with more responsibility. But that's not the norm. It's rare for BOS to be given promotions outside of the contact center. A lot of BOS really want to move on to other positions, they want more responsibility. But there's no room for professional development. All you do as a BOS is take calls and do data entry. Very rarely are any other responsibilities available. 

Promotions are incredibly competitive, and there are a lot of talented, smart, and dedicated BOS. But a lot of new jobs  on the other side of BDT end up going to external candidates. It feels like the stories of growth are told just to placate us. 

Management is always saying they want to hear our feedback, but they never listen unless it's positive feedback.  They know we want to be paid more, they know we feel like we're treated like children, and they rarely address these issues. When they do, their feedback is vague. The job is very defeating, and the support systems that are in place aren't enough.

review_title: The most significant professional experience of my life.
pros: The main reason to work at Benefits Data Trust is a connectivity to the mission.  Look to join the BDT team if you are interested in making a tangible difference in the lives of under-served, vulnerable populations.  Here, you work alongside collaborative, mission-oriented colleagues who truly want to serve and improve the lives of those who need a safety net during difficult times.  I joined as a Benefits Outreach Specialist years ago and was armed with all of the appropriate tools and resources to support clients through a sometimes complex application process.  Throughout my time at BDT, I always had access to a mentor (whether formal or informal) who remained committed to my professional growth and development.  Accessible senior leadership is dedicated to developing team members for advancement as the organization grows.  On a personal note, I've experienced significant personal hardship during my employment and was embraced by an amazing support system that allowed me to get back on my feet.  This organization's mission to help those in need transcends beyond the clients; it reaches the employees as well.
cons: Benefits package is very competitive unless you need to provide Medical coverage to spouse/partner/dependents

review_title: BDT is committed to its mission and to its employees, and is a very open, positive and rewarding place to work.
pros:
At BDT, you are able to positively impact the lives of those in need at a scale that is not possible in most other not-for-profit organizations

The management team is open, supportive, and engages staff at all levels of the organization. There is significant opportunity for personal and professional growth.

The people who work here are friendly, fun, and committed to making a difference by addressing social issues such as poverty, hunger, and access to health care.
cons: As with any call center, the work can be challenging and a lot of time is spent on the phone at your desk. However, there are no quotas or demands to complete phone calls under a certain amount of time as in other call centers. The emphasis is always on high quality conversations and good interactions with clients.

review_title: I met some of the best people ever even though I can't say the job was one of the best ever.
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
-Very relaxed dress code
-Extremely kind and supportive co-workers
-Accessible and friendly upper management
-Easy going work environment; everyone gets his/her own desk cubicle
-Regular one-on-one coaching sessions with your supervisor
-Great location in a swanky high rise in center city Philly.
-The work hours for this position are standard. Rarely will you work past 5 pm and you don't have to take work home with you.
cons:
-70% of your day will be spent yelling at old people on the phone who can't hear well.
-Expensive medical insurance in relation to the  low hourly wages.
-No vacation or sick time, just 2 weeks' worth of PTO for the whole year.
-VERY  stringent bathroom and break policies.
-Daily work policies and procedures are often unclear .
-Not a lot of room for advancement; there are a limited amount of new opportunities with a huge and always growing amount of employees.

review_title: Great for 1 year or less/then run
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Hourly pay is decent and the location is perfect.  Very casual dress is allowed.  The work is all about helping people.  None of the staffing ups and downs of some not for proftit companies because of government subcontracts.
cons:
It's 95% automated telephone work.  The work feels shady after 6 months.  Call center staff could be treated better with more time off, better benefits, and flexible hours.  You don't have to ask permission to use the restroom, but you do have to let at least one person know before you go.  That person could ask you to wait a few before going.  
Very little room for open criticism.  Management asks, but as soon as you give it prepare for their collective wrath. Most staff is under 30 years old.

pros: I have always been the very shy and quiet type. I've always been a very hard worker,but was always overlooked for not saying enough. BDT gave me the opportunity to have my voice be heard.  Management is beyond friendly, welcoming and dedicated to their employees. The atmosphere is beyond anything you could ever imagine. With incentives to be earned daily, parties to be had nearly monthly and co-workers beyond belief. This is the epitome of what one dreams to have from a workplace. I can honestly say that Benefits Data Trust is a place where I'd love to retire from.
cons: The one con that I can say on behalf of Benefits Outreach Specialist, are the minimum amount of Paid Time Off days that offered. With that said, you are made well aware of this during your interview. So if you accept it, you should not complain.

review_title: Incredible working environment and a job that helps make a difference!
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Phila, PA
pros:
BDT has the best working environment I have ever encountered. Co-workers and superiors alike are positive, supportive and share a passion for helping people. 

I constantly felt encouraged to speak up about any issues or concerns I had about the company and was surrounded by endless support by my peers and superiors. 

While all employees take their work seriously there is also a wonderful emphasis on light-hearted fun. While I was working there the management team organized outings and in office activities that brought the company workers together in a fun and creative way.

The job itself, while sometimes challenging and somewhat monotonous, was gratifying because with every phone call I took I knew I was helping the person on the other end. 

I highly recommend BDT to anyone who values a positive and supportive work environment along with a job that makes an impact in the world.
cons: The job itself can after a while feel monotonous. It is a position that takes patience and a mind for detail.

review_title: Many ups and downs, inconsistencies and frustrations
pros: Working at BDT allows for a steady 9-5 schedule, you never have to bring work home, and there is work events that are sometimes enjoyable such as pot lucks and trivia.
cons: BDT's positive mission is slowly but surely falling far from practice. Since I have been there, I have seen the customer service, quality of work, and satisfaction of clients (and community organizations) dwindle steadily. Management receives large incentives and annual bonuses while others do not receive anything which is unfair. Many of the staff here are on the public benefits that they help people apply for (food stamps, heating assistance, etc.) because the pay is not sufficient.

review_title: Benefits Data Trust offers a very rewarding professional experience
pros: Benefits Data Trust was a remarkable place to work for a variety of reasons. They support and challenge their employees to grow professionally. The well-being of the individuals and families they serve is paramount. The staff supports one another while allowing and challenging employees to learn and grow independently. The management is attuned to the needs of their staff and their partners, and always aim to accommodate and help internal and external stakeholders alike - they also welcome and accept feedback from all staff. When challenges arose, the organization's philosophy was to own the challenge, seek solutions, learn from the experience, and move forward. Finally, the atmosphere is a combination of driven, warm, and fun, which makes for a very rewarding and engaging professional life.
cons: There were no major cons of working with Benefits Data Trust.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Phila, PA
pros: casual dress and great COWORKERS when I was there. Pay is solid in comparison to other Non profit agencies
cons:
Management is a joke! There is no room or flexibility at all. They make ask your opinion but they dont really want it. You get pulled into meetings and put on probation constantly over the slighest "wrinkling of feather" to direct superviors. I am extremely professional and they are not at all, but promote it then dont follow their own rules. 

THERE IS NO ROOM FOR ADVANCEMENT AT ALL. THERE IS NO SENORITY AT ALL!!! 

Sure you help people most of the time but it is a pain in the A#$, especially when youhave to call seniors out of the blue and ask them 100 questions to complete an application. 

This job is perfect for someone who likes to suck up to management and loves talking on the phone to incompetent, hard of hearing seniors.

review_title: My experience at BDT was mostly a waste of time, but I did learn about how narrow-minded people can be.
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It is something to put on the resume. If you are unemployed and this is all you can find other than a fast food restsurant job, then work at BDT.
cons: Management is really one-sided and does not like being challenged. They ask for feedback, but they are only looking for compliments. Management is strict about political correctness, but people in management are nasty themselves in many ways. They cannot be trusted to keep their word. It is best to keep a low-profile and get out of there asap.

pros: Strong Purpose - clear mission and focus; Awesome, smart & engaged team - at all levels; A clear focus on staff development; Demonstrated success in delivering positive social change - for individuals in need,  the health & human services systems that serve them and the communities in which they live.
cons: We are a social change organization that operates a contact center - extremely well.  Contact center work can be regimented and challenging.  We work hard to balance efficiency - in order to help as many people as possible - with staff autonomy and flexibility.    This is an area that needs continual attention.

pros: The company offers a great benefits package. Matching 401k.
cons: The management team is very disrespectful. They don't even have the respect to say good morning. They don't acknowledge workers unless they've did something wrong. The company has a strong  policy for privacy, but yet every room consist of glass walls. There is no room for part-time. They preach room for advancement, but it is based on how much they like you rather than skills and experience. They announced layoffs today and within an hour, dozens were gone.  Though the organization is not for profit, it is sales based.

pros: Diversity is not just a word here.  Employees are asked upon hire, about their preference of gender pronoun.  Management strives to learn how to best manage a largely millennial workforce.  The organization is growing so there is growth opportunity in all directions.  This is a nonprofit that really cares about its mission and culture.  All employees are vital to the Organization's mission and we all know it.   The work/life balance here is fantastic and the work is meaningful.  I would highly recommend working here.
cons: The spousal health benefit is very pricey and unrealistic.  However, the employee health insurance is very affordable and comprehensive. The benefits in general are very good.

pros:
The BOS position is good in a few scenarios. It's a good position for those who just graduated or are still going to school. It's good for those who are looking for a career change and want some non profit and/or customer service experience. It's also good for those who are looking for a long term position but dont really care to make much money or move up career wise (like people who are just working to work).

Office is brand new and very cool. Great location. Young staff.
cons:
The pay. I mean c'mon. First 90 days you get $14/hr. After that you get $15hr. After a year you have the POTENTIAL of get UP TO a dollar raise...you can do everything right and not get that dollar because they're not willing to give that dollar raise out. Most people end up getting a .25 or .50 cent raise after a year and the best BOS get .75. BDT can't even give us a full 40 hour work week (37.5)

A promotion from BOS to a coordinator position really just means a lot more responsibilities for not that much pay (coordinator positions pay 38k). Many smart, hard working and capable BOS go out for these positions but they end up going with an external candidate OR someone else in the office who didn't even go out for that promotion! 

BOS are micromanaged to the point where it seems like upper management thinks we're idiotic children. No internet access because of "data security" but everyone else in the office has access to the same info we do and they have internet. No phones at our desks and in designated areas. 30 min break and 45 min lunch. Basically anytime you do anything you have to set your status on your computer so everyone else knows what you're up to while people in other departments chill in the break room all the time.

They even audit some peoples instant messages to each out (which can lead to termination) when HR has their own scandalous drama going on...hypocrites

BDT continues to expand rather than focusing on the issues that the staff are voicing over and over again. Everyone in the contact center is miserable and we all find solice in that. It's been basically accepted that BDT will crash and burn soon enough because everyone wants to leave at this point. A cool office isn't enough to keep your staff.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Thorough training, supportive management, great culture. The office is located right by the Comcast building, so the commute is easy from anywhere in the city. There are a lot of fun employee events like potlucks and occasional parties. Definitely room for advancement.
cons: Smaller company, competitive promotions, low starting pay. Everyone starts in the call center. There's seems to be a disconnect between management and the rest of the company. You can't use your cell phone in the contact center. Breaks are timed and short, HR rules are really strict here.  I know they're meant to protect people, but it ends up just being stifling.

job_title: Manager (On the Administrative Side) in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Compared to other nonprofits, this place is honestly run really well. Obviously there are some comments here to the contrary, but anyone who has worked at two or more nonprofits in the social services sphere has expressed a pleasant surprise at how thoughtfully managed this place is.

I've worked at 7+ nonprofits in this field and this is the best one I've even been a part of.

The benefits are very good.
cons: Growth in a time of government shrinkage is hard, but we are weathering it together with the state and other community-based organizations in our 7 states.

review_title: Most degrading job I ever had
pros: Good resume builder and some good people working there. The location is nice. Comcast center is near by.
cons: Very condescending and duplicitous supervisors. There is a very pretentious pretentious culture. Supervisors smile in your face and pretend to be your friends, but then micromanage you and call you out for things that are either imagined by them or mistakes that they make on a daily basis. Certainly the lower level employees are treated like children and are severely underpaid and overworked. Breaks are too short. By the time you finish in the bathroom, you need to rush to eat your lunch and get back to work.

review_title: A great place to learn and grow
pros:
Benefits data trust is an excellent environment for individuals that take feedback and ownership of their development/career. I was fortunate to grow and learn at BDT.

BDT has a great culture that does a great job of fostering individuality and innovation. The people working at BDT really care about each other and are doing their best to help the mission
cons: Every organization that you will work for has issues that it needs to work on and fix. BDT at least listens and does its best to improve. As BDT grows, they should continue to slow down and not make decisions to quickly. Make sure to bring every one along!

review_title: Strong group of professionals who genuinely enjoy working together for a worthy mission.
pros: BDT affords its employees meaningful, challenging work. Coworkers are diverse in background and skill set, adding to the professional culture. The environment is challenging (in a good way) and also light and fun - keeping the team energized and focused on the work at hand and the people we serve every day.
cons: Because BDT is a smaller organization, opportunities for professional advancement are not plentiful and are highly competitive, which in a way is good because it pushes us all as individuals to be our best at all times.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great co-workers. BDT hires a diverse staff of passionate, intelligent people as BOS, mostly on the younger side. LGBTQ-inclusive workplace. Decent pay and benefits for a first job outside of college (or in my case, coming out of two years serving in AmeriCorps). Stable hours. Convenient location. *~*~ Hip Millennial Office *~*~*

As a BOS, you learn A LOT about the public benefits system. Helping clients navigate the system can be genuinely rewarding, and I’ve had some beautiful conversations I’ll never forget. Very eye-opening work.
cons:
The organization has been growing at an unsustainable rate over the past year, then this past week they laid off an alarming amount of admin workers, many of whom had been promoted from the BOS role. As a high-performing BOS with professional growth on my mind, this is disheartening, to say the least. We have been assured that BOS are safe, as our funding for direct service is secure, but the admin layoffs have been a giant blow to organizational morale and any hopes of professional growth. 

In my view, the organization has cut corners in places that matter the most when it comes to directly serving our clients with competency and care. For example, training for new BOS was drastically shortened earlier in the year. New hires were pushed onto the phones too soon, making critical errors that stalled clients’ benefit applications. I can only imagine the sacrifices in quality that will occur in the near future due to the cutting of team leaders, quality specialists, and project coordinators. 

I will echo what others have said here about the micro-management of BOS. I once got a time management memo for swiping in 2 seconds late (after two other latenesses within a month, both under one minute late) which, as someone who puts a lot of heart and soul into the parts of the job that really matter, felt unnecessarily petty.

I’ll also echo what others have said about the facade of “feedback culture.” There are lots of BOS and TLs with great ideas….but it often feels like those ideas get stuck at “yeah we’re just waiting to get the okay from management.” It is deflating. This organization was founded to make the public benefits system more efficient, yet here we are, drowning in inefficiency. Simple solutions stalling in the bureaucracy.

pros: Great co-workers. Good effort on the part of management to build a strong culture when employees are not on the phone.
cons: Constant phone calls. Low pay. Great group of co-workers, but these co-workers are also competition for small amount of opportunities for advancement. Often folks who are highly qualified for promotions are passed-over because there are so many qualified candidates in the pool.

pros: The hours are consistent. This space couldn't be left blank, so there you go. You know exactly what your shifts will be. That is THE positive.
cons: Please notice how every time they get several negative (aka honest) reviews, an "anonymous" employee posts a vague & glowing review. This should indicate how they operate right there: they will take your feedback and brush it all away. They don't care. We just moved to this glitzy office space, but you know how that money could have been spent? By paying us more, by not withholding pto-you get 16 days/year, but they release half the days for half the year, by not timing our bathroom breaks, by actually listening to us. The healthcare isn't even that good.

review_title: Lots of potential, lots of pitfalls
pros:
BDT is a smart and innovative organization that cares about quality and does good work. In my time at BDT, I learned a lot and certainly feel that my experience there helped me to grow professionally. 

BDT is a diverse organization that - at least in good moments - genuinely strives to be self-reflective and solutions oriented.

BDT is rapidly growing,  which provided opportunities for some people to advance, and/or move into areas of personal interest.

Most of all, BDT is filled with lots of inspiring, hard working, caring and quirky individuals. Even on the worst days, there are people there to pick you up and make you laugh.
cons:
During this period of aggressive organizational growth BDT has prioritized this growth over quality. At one point, the mantra was to respect and value the work we had in house first and foremost, but at some point there was a clear shift away from this value.

BDT at times exhibits deep hypocrisy. With a mission of addressing poverty and helping vulnerable families and communities, BDT should not be taking funding from companies that produce poverty, or failing to pay employees a living wage. While front line staff can earn $15/hr this is barely enough to survive, and it is well known that upper level management earn very generous salaries- even more than the average for their positions in the field

In my experience, BDT is not truly open to feedback on an organizational level. Certain managers truly are, but at the end of the day change is dictated from the top-down and there is a serious lack of transparency in decision making.

I experienced and witnessed a toxic culture of nepotism. Ultimately, if you don't smile and agree with the decision makers, you cannot progress.

pros: Dress code is relax, starting hourly pay rate is ok if you are fresh out of college or need a job. One step up from minimum wage. Great job to put on your resume. Great Co workers.
cons: You have to be prepared to suck up. BDT is a place that promotes based on your personality and NOT your work ethic, performance or seniority. If you are a ray of sunshine with no passion to work then please apply @ BDT. If you are a hard dedicated worker that wants to advance then DON'T apply @ BDT. Constantly in meetings over hear say, hear say dictates pay raises and promotions. Children teaching children. Management love feed back if its gossip. Management love to play "we are all equal" card but that is a lie. Management brings their pets into work on a regular basis but will not allow you to bring your child to work day or to a work events. Please do not look to do excellent work for a year and expect a decent raise. Excellent workers will get the same raise as BAD worker (no need to do or want more ). Employees are leaving WITHOUT finding new jobs. That's how bad it sucks in there. You will rather quit with any money or job than to be unhappy and wasting precious time. I never worked at a job that does so much talking and gets nothing done. WOW!

review_title: Great management and organization, but call center work requires thick skin
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The management truly cares about their employees, and you can honestly say that you're making a difference in people's lives.  I was there during a transition period where the organization received new leadership in the call center and it made all the difference in the world.  They use customized software that makes a huge difference in making conversations with clients efficient as well as make your life easier  It is a tough job, but the leadership often promotes from within and is great at providing the resources needed to make your job possible.  I had some incredible moments with both our clients and my coworkers, and I am thankful for my time at BDT.
cons: It is a tough gig.  You are on the phone for roughly eight hours a day talking to clients who are senior citizens.  Phone calls are a constant, and there is often not a lot of down time without calls.  Some of this is making phone calls to clients that already have one benefit but may be eligible for another.  Much like making outbound sales calls, this requires having a thick skin.  Although you are not "selling" anything, you are also explaining very complex benefits to clients in a very short amount of time while estimating their eligibility at the same time.

pros: BDT had a significant impact on the professional I am today. I came to BDT straight out of college as BOS for a mission I felt extremely passionate about. The level of passion BDT has about the clients they serve also extends to the staff through the structured and successful professional development program in the contact center. Loving what I did as a BOS, I knew that there were additional ways I could contribute to BDT by working towards becoming a team leader and later a manager. What is extremely unique about BDT is the level of feedback you have access to whether that be through your peers, manager, or other member's of the organization. The candidness of this feedback is what allowed me to successful. If you are open to hearing about not only what you have done well, but also what you have room to work on, you will thrive here. I am forever grateful for the feedback that I received in my three years at BDT because it helped me to grow professionally in ways I never could have imagined as a young college grad. My praise for BDT is endless and I can't thank my co-workers and managers enough for the support and team work that I experienced in my three years. Specifically, to my managers, without whom I never would have been challenged to become the professional I am today, I am forever grateful. If you are a passionate individual, who is mission centered, not afraid to roll up your sleeves and work hard, then BDT is place for you. Although I am happy in my new place of work, I miss BDT and the culture there everyday.
cons: No Cons that I can think of. If you work hard, listen to feedback, implement it, and grow then this is the place for you. If it weren't for an opportunity to join the family business, I would be writing this as a current employee.

pros:
There are genuinely great people with great ideas who work here. 

Work is steady and management is generally flexible with schedules or when you have circumstances outside of work that need to be dealt with. It's very difficult to get fired unless you arrive late every day.
cons:
A lot of promotions are based on personal popularity or based on it being an employees "turn" for a promotion. Employees who don't truly posses the qualifications for a higher position are placed in the position anyway. This leaves a lot of gaping holes where a team leader or manager *should* be able to coach their team, but because they lack the skills or knowledge they needed in the first place, their attempts at managing or coaching are completely ineffective. 

Low-level employees are treated like they're in kindergarten, having to time and account for each second of the day, including bathroom breaks, while high level managers do whatever they like, regardless of the rules. There were a few days in a row when a high level employee brought their baby into work for the entire workday, but if a  BOS did this, they would immediately be told how inappropriate it is. 

Management pretends very very hard that they want to hear feedback from low-level employees, but only if it's something they wanted to hear in the first place. Someone brings up an idea with valid arguments for it, it gets shot down by management because "that's the way we've always done it" and then two months later a manager "comes up with" the same idea, and it's treated as the best idea in the world. BDT even had an outside non-profit come in to help figure out what they were doing wrong. Employees were able to give candid, hard-to-hear feedback. Management interpreted most of the feedback as positive and nothing ever truly changed. Ego and competing toxic personalities really hold this organization back from being great. 

BDT is stepping away from quality in general. As the organization grows, they can't manage training so many people, so training has been shortened and new BOS have far less support than they used to. It very much felt like quantity (having a warm body in each seat and a voice to answer the phone) was more important than quality by far. Another reviewer said it was the most corporate non-profit they ever encountered and I would agree.

review_title: My two years of working here turned out to be the single most fulfilling, challenging experiences of my career so far.
pros:
*Their approach to nonprofit work makes it possible to reach thousands of clients a month, and at the end of each work day I had no doubt that I’d made a difference in many people’s lives.
*I’ve always had a lot of responsibilities on my plate at BDT and was always supported to find my own best way to handle those responsibilities. 
*Since leaving BDT I do not expect to find any other position that matches the support they provide to their employees.  Each staff member meets regularly with their supervisor whether they´re in need of improvement, exceeding expectations, or simply meeting their performance standards.
*There is a ton of room for growth in this dynamic organization. They were founded a mere 6 years ago, and are still forming. They constantly experiment to find the best way to accomplish their goals. Creative ideas are solicited and often implemented immediately.
cons: This is not the job for someone looking for easy work. Its for someone who is ready to work hard, and wants to get on board with a team of dedicated coworkers to make a difference in the lives of older adults struggling to pay their bills.

pros: I was so inspired each day I worked here to leave that I searched for another job several times a day!
cons:
Why bother listing any cons? The HR department will come along and write a reply to reviews that list valid concerns on glassdoor with a "Thanks!! Our culture IS great!!" type response. 

Management is petty, childish, and inexperienced. It is entry level work at best with little to no advancement. Get ready to drink your koolaid if you work there, and spike it to deal with each day.

The positive reviews are seeded by Benefits Data Trust to counteract all the honest ones. Let's see how fast a positive one will be listed after this one is posted!

pros: In addition to a worthy mission, real impact, and innovative program design, the work environment is supportive and collaborative.Staff genuinely care about both the product and one another. There are multiple opportunities for feedback with direct supervisors and the President. Overall, the organization wants to make sure both the service to the clients and to the staff is strong.
cons: Fast paced environment means new, unexpected demands can come in.

review_title: An awesome internship that allowed me to learn and work with great people.
job_title: External Relations Intern in Philadelphia, PA
pros: BDT is an extremely welcoming environment-- everyone is willing to lend a helping hand and show you how things work. People are warm and engaging, as well as intelligent and focused. You can learn so much simply by example at BDT. On top of that, BDT is an awesome operation that is truly unique and will allow you to learn a lot.
cons: During my time at BDT, I truly didn't experience any cons.

pros: Benefits Data Trust is a great organization to work for, they are very patient and detailed about any training necessary to ensure you are ready to work proficiently. This organization stream lines the application process for the Department of Human Services  of Pennsylvania benefits for several states in the U.S.  From upper management to administrative staff they are pleasant to work with.
cons: In my opinion there are no negatives or downsides working at Benefits Data Trust

pros: Casual dress code. Close to transportation. Pay is better than other non-profits. Good benefits.
cons: No room for advancement at all. Seems like seniority/ time invested into the company does not matter. Mostly Outbound call center work which makes you feel like a telemarketer. Feels kind of like school in the sense where you have to let people know when you are going on break, lunch, bathroom, etc. They ask for feedback but really only want positive feedback.

review_title: A gem in my professional experience
pros:
The mission. The people. The working environment. The support. The culture. The benefits. The opportunities. The fun. 

BDT is unparalleled to any other organization I know. There is a collective drive to serve the mission with compassion, integrity, and excellence while supporting one another along the way.
cons: If it weren't for an opportunity to pursue a lifelong dream, I would be posting this review as a current employee.

review_title: Be careful about accepting a BOS position.
pros: People care about the mission and most of the staff is young. The space is beautiful and the views of the city are great. This organization is also  a very LGBTQ friendly place to work. Your team leader generally does care about you and wants to see you succeed and team members are generally supportive and caring. You will meet some of the most amazing and passionate people in this office.
cons:
Before I started here over a year ago, I read the glassdoor reviews and took them with a grain of salt because I assumed the negative reviews were from jilted employees.  Now that I have seen the other side, most of the negative reviews from BOS are valid. I look back on my time at BDT with fondess but I am thankful that I found something better suited for my professional needs. 

As a BOS, you're going to be answering calls from clients, often in traumatic situations and applying them for public benefits. This is your main job function and its honestly emotionally exhausting and demoralizing most days. A part of being a BOS is being micromanaged constantly and management treats you like children.  This job is not for the faint of heart, or for those who want experience that is not client service. BDT hires talented, idealistic individuals and then breaks down their spirits until they simply cannot do the job any longer. 

Additionally, there is barely any room for growth and it is well known that management plays favorites. Often, they will interview a ton of BOS for an open position and then hire externally or go with an internal candidate who is not a BOS. On top of this, the pay is horrible and not competitive at all. The structure for raises is abysmal: you can  get at most $1 raise a year and that is only if you're lucky. You can go above and beyond, have amazing calls, be on small teams and still only get a .50 raise. So you go from making $15/hour to $15.50, which just shows that your labor is not valued. If you have student loans and want to plan for you future, this job is not sustainable for you, unless you want to work multiple part-time jobs on top of this. 

Also, from the start of my employment, I always got the feeling that the Admin side of the organization looked down on BOS. I was not alone in the feeling that there is an unequal balance of power in this organization.It's a shame that the cons outweigh the pros because BDT has the potential to be a great place to work, but the way the organization is structured makes it impossible for you to be a BOS and not feel the constrains of the position.

review_title: Toxic doesn’t even begin to describe this place.
pros:
The job was better when I first started, but they've changed. If you have a great TL, the job is better. I had several different ones in my tenure, and completely different experiences with each of them. The last one I had was the final nail in my patience for the place, and despite having several easily actionable feedback items for them, none of them were acted upon. I know, because I’ve kept in touch with friends from there.  There are precisely 3 great TLs across all capaigns. 

The pay is okay for a single person with minimal debt and who has roommates and a lower than average cost of living for the area.
cons:
They want you not to be human. I worked here for longer than I should have, and was excellent at the actual function of the job itself.  My problem with it is how much abuse they expect BOS to take from the clients while maintaining a 100% neutral response. Now, I don’t mean a few curses from the client. I had clients go on racist, homophobic, sexist rants, and more. Management expected us to take it without even blinking. If you show any emotion, you’re told you’re being judgemental/inappropriate and get marked down that you need improvement.  I’ve had extensive experience in other call centers, and none of them worked like that. I repeatedly went to management with both proactive ways to both improve the overall office and to help us do our job better that required nothing out of them except listening and being respected as a person, only to be ignored. 

The staff often are miserable to each other, doing things they know will harm themselves or those around them.  I can’t entirely blame them. The majority of BOS are on the same public benefits they help others apply for. Get any three staff together, they'll mostly talk about how much they hate the place and the things they do to cope. Every time I talk to friends who still work there, all I can think is how glad I am not to be there anymore.

Even beyond all those problems, they inflate their numbers. They pressure callers to apply with vague and incorrect information, and they get money based on the raw number of applications. They don’t care if someone’s already enrolled or ineligible. Just apply them anyway, let the caseworkers sort it out.  They’re draining the resources of the already strained system by ineffectively using the limited resources. They don't take advantage of ways the workflow could be optimized, like using the most skilled workers for the tasks they're best suited for or encouraging people to apply with the most accurate information they can reasonably easily get. Like, if the wife handles the finances, she should be the one calling. If your niece handles your affairs, she should call in. But don't dare suggest it, or they think it's call avoidance. They waste so much money with frivolous activities, including last year a "fundraiser" that tried to pressure employees to donate on their paltry hourly wage. Really out of touch, when so many of us with families there are barely scraping by.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: You will notice all of the 5 star reviews are for people in Managment positions. Thier jobs are good and well paid, not so for the BOS.
cons: This job is good for entry level employees only. The BOS position is a call center job, that is all. There will be promises of upward mobility but they are rare to say the least. You will be scheduled to work 37.5 hours a week, so that you can not reach overtime, even though you will be expected to stay late in calls. One huge draw back of this job is the way they treat their staff like children, starting off everyday a female team leader will shout like a steam whistle " it's 9am!!" In what can only be described as a stern kindergarten teacher voice. This will be the start of many ways daily you are treated like a child. If you do not appreciate micro Managment this is not the position for you. The level of micro Managment is staggering, from every bathroom break being timed, call monitoring to a document system that will literally set you up to fail. If you appreciate independence in the workplace avoid this job. The pay for the work is low especially considering how hard the job actually is, this will become immediately frustrating once you realize how much upper Managment is allowing themselves to take as a salary, with bonuses, something you will never get. Something you will be told in training, " you have the hardest job in the company" and yet you will get the least. This is a not-for profit, Not a non-profit, there is a difference you will see it in the high expectations and low pay. Many BOS qualify for the benefits we are helping people apply for. If you just graduated from college and need a resume filler this IS a good postion.

pros: Everyone is passionate about the mission of the organization and works really hard, which is great motivation.  The organization is growing - lots of opportunity to develop professionally.
cons: No major cons - again, everyone works really hard, but it's a great job for anyone motivated and inspired by the mission.

review_title: Want to be treated like an adult? Not on company time.
pros: You can use your break time to apply for benefits you assist clients with since, pay is low enough you can qualify. Fills a gap in your resume(?) You won't be alone.... feeling like this place drains you.
cons:
Management is a jekyll and hyde situation. "Coaching"means being picked apart made to feel small and unimportant since you don't get a voice. After being shown all the ways you should be better at a cubicle soul sucking job you are forced to play scattegories with your camp counselor TL. If you don't play games you are labeled as negative and not a team player by the very person that can't even answer questions clients bombard you with. Be careful though, the kool aid needs to be drunk if you want to move up, your actual performance will not matter .

Yes, this is a call center, yes you talk to people in terrible/sad situations everyday and fill out applications for them but do not go into this thinking you are doing much good in the world. I did and my expectations were too high. Again as other reviews point out your time is micromanaged since you need to answer the phone. you have to be ok with it if you take this job. Back to the jekyll and hyde management, they boast open door policy but don't want to hear what you might say if you don't agree with their status quo. If you are young you will be treated like a child, but if you are an older person, as I am, you will be treated like a dinosaur, since you will be condescended to frequently!

pros: The only pro I would say is the benefits packet and how nice the office is.
cons: I worked at BDT for about 9 months or so. I eagerly went into this opportunity, ecstatic, nonetheless because I was unemployed and needed a job but after interviewing and slightly seeing the environment, I was ready for a fresh start. Typically you start off in one campaign, which I did with a great team of folks , my TL was awesome ,really down to earth and personable ( she had a great balance). The class that I came in with were full of quick learners and we were often praised for that, after noticing that , they used to their advantage to get us to take on new roles. A friend from my new class and I were asked to move to another campaign , in which they claimed it would be a chance for professional development and could help with movement within the organization. I was very skeptical, very and wish I followed my gut.  Prior to moving to their campaign,  I heard how unstructured this particular campaign but heard it was a lighter load. While transitioning,  so was the campaign, increasing their outreach letters, calls, etc. Once I made the move the environment was completely different , no one really spoke. A lot of pettiness and betrayal was going on and ALOT OF MICRO MANAGING. As the time went on the work load got crazy , we were taking damn near 30 calls a day, people were exhausted draining all of their break times and running over lunch. We felt so unappreciated and small and it was clear their only goal was to increase their numbers and reach their goal. I learned how much they dont care about their workers, it took lots of complaining for them to do things like bring in donuts, lunch and for us to be noticed for all the work we were doing ( of course this came after tons of people quit or got fired). The environment is chill but very childish full of grown people who dont know how to mind their business, are interested in stirring drama,  or are dating one another. They dont respect your personal time and are penalized for taking longer than 3 minutes after calls to recouparate. The campaign I moved to is lead by the fakest human being I have ever met, she smiles in your face but will literally talk about you behind your back. The staff is super unprofessional, they weigh heavier on time management ( which they have a horrible policy that never works in your favor) more than the actual work that you do, they chose favorites for everything and are not realistic to the fact that their workers are human beings not robots. I would never work here, again! I wouldn't recommend it and in fact I was let go due to time management and I was so happy to finally have a peace of mind again! I dont regret leaving, I was looking for a way out anayways.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Easy work most of the time. Kind of rewarding  as Social service work and very predictable almost every day of the week.
cons: They use fear and boring to work at. Everything you do is a mistake and it is basically a call center.

pros: You will notice almost all of the positive reviews are from employees that work above the BOS title, their jobs and pay are good.
cons: This is a good entry level job, that is all, a resume builder at best. This job is exhausting and the hardest in the company yet you will be paid the least. This company has little respect for you as an employee, from scheduling BOS at 37.5 house a week so that they can avoid overtime pay ( which you will be expected to work if you get a late call) to timing ever moment of your day by limiting and recording  all of your bathroom breaks. This " not for profit" is run like any other private sector company so get ready to meet deadlines, sell things to people that don't want them and work really hard so that the Managment can get  bonuses and big salaries while you and your family qualify for the benefits we are helping people enroll in ( Food stamps & Medical assistance). The constant need to treat the BOS like children is infuriating , from the beginning of your shift a female team leader will literally yell " it's 9am" like a steam horn in a factory, in a tone that can only be described as stern kindergarten teacher, and order to make the working conditions seem easier people will give you candy and high fives in hopes of lifting your dismal spirits from being yelled at by strangers for 8 hours a day. At this job you will be micro managed in ever sense of the word, middle managers will watch and monitor everything you do, critiques will be given in the classic private sector style, " meets expectations" will be the most positve feedback you can get in most reviews, which you will have bi-weekly. Most of the BOS are overqualified to say the least , you will be surrounded by amazing coworkers ( best part of job) most of whom will not be promoted from within.

pros: The atmosphere is amazing, and there are so many kind and compassionate people that work here. I have always felt truly supported in my professional development journey and know the work we are doing is helping so many.
cons: Fast growth caused some bumps in the road, but appropriate changes have been made to improve things.

review_title: Good company, above average pay and wonderful management!
job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The pay is much higher than any other non-profit phone job.  The entire management staff is very approachable, flexible and respectful.
cons: Too many overeducated, socially conscious, self righteous people at once can be overload.  There are lots of annoying college students that work here.

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Basically everything, but to be specific, the people are wonderful, the administration is caring and thoughtful, you can be yourself and just relax in the work environment, good PTO, etc. etc. etc.
cons: It's a call center. Most people start out as a BOS, calling clients. Any customer service job can be a little tricky.

pros: Great coworkers and work atmosphere. Employees promoted are deserving (I liked the team leaders I worked under.) Casual dress code. Decent pay for call center work. Performance expectations are obtainable.
cons: Upward mobility somewhat limited, so many people remain in the same position for quite a while. Duties and tasks were repetitive, but that's part of call center work.

pros: Open collaborative environment.  Allows individuals to grow professionally.  Promotes from within. Values diversity.
cons: can always do more.  more professional development opportunities

pros: the staff is amazing.  The environment is very positive and people are being helped in the process.  you work with good people for a good cause
cons: it can be very tedious

job_title: Benefits Outreach Specialist in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Writing this as fields cannot remain unfilled. What's shocking is, Glassdoor would not ask this of anyone who works at Benefits Data Trust.
cons: Underpaid, must use break time to relieve yourself, promote a faux "fun" culture, costly health benefits, no bonuses, glaringly different treatment than salaried staff, feel like killing myself everyday.

pros: Good place to land on your feet or get experience if you don't have any.
cons: Employees treated like replaceable cogs.

pros: Good coworkers and  nothing else nothing at all zip zero nada nothing and I mean Nothing at all (had to fill in the 20 words)
cons: Low pay,micro management,break times, Ego inflated company that worries  more about their "partners" than their BOS(heart &soul) millions spent on a nice office instead of the employees more.
